snippet: The program is the only safety net for millions of middle-class people whose needs for long-term care, at home or in a nursing home, outlast their resources.
abstract: Many states faced with rising Medicaid costs and budget deficits are trying to cut the cost of long-term care by profoundly changing Medicaid coverage, through the use of federal waivers; waivers sought or obtained by 26 states would affect some three million people, most of them eligible for both Medicaid and Medicare; plans vary, but typically they try to cut costs by giving private managed-care organizations a fixed sum for a lifetime of care.
lead_paragraph: The program is the only safety net for millions of middle-class people whose needs for long-term care, at home or in a nursing home, outlast their resources.

headline.main: With Medicaid, Long-Term Care of Elderly Looms as a Rising Cost
